issue.title: Operations get duplicated

labels.name: won't fix 🛑
labels.description: This issue won't be fixed as part of the current roadmap

issue.body:
### Describe the bug

I use urql in a nuxt 3 project and see duplicated operations when they should only get triggered once.

```
[Exchange debug]: Incoming operation:  
{key: 3495087222, query: Object, variables: Object, kind: "query", context: Object}
{timestamp: 1663681014862, source: "fetchExchange", type: "fetchRequest", message: "A fetch request is being executed.", operation: Object…}
[Exchange debug]: Incoming operation:  
{key: 3495087222, query: Object, variables: Object, kind: "query", context: Object}
{timestamp: 1663681014865, source: "fetchExchange", type: "dedup", message: "An operation has been deduped.", operation: Object}
{timestamp: 1663681015610, source: "fetchExchange", type: "fetchSuccess", message: "A successful fetch response has been returned.", operation: Object…}
```

Note that I'm aware that the `dedupExchange` blocks this duplicate request. But I'd rather consider this a workaround. The second operation should not be executed in the first place.

I added some `console.log()` to the urql sources and was able to track it down to this part of the code in `client.ts`:

https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/blob/0582f9b138ddb66c5164b00a978aac90e865c0dc/packages/core/src/client.ts#L302

The callback passed to `make()` gets called **twice** and hence the same operation in `onStart()` is dispatched again somehow. I could not figure out, why this happens.

The documentation on Wonka's [make](https://wonka.kitten.sh/api/sources#make) says:

> The function you pass to make is called lazily when a sink subscribes to the source you’re creating.

So I would expect that this is only called once. Not sure if this is maybe rather a bug in wonka.


### Reproduction

https://codesandbox.io/s/urql-duplicate-operation-yfp2ei

### Urql version

* @urql/core 3.0.3
* @urql/vue 1.0.2

### Validations

- [X] I can confirm that this is a bug report, and not a feature request, RFC, question, or discussion, for which [GitHub Discussions](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/discussions) should be used
- [X] Read the [docs](https://formidable.com/open-source/urql/docs/).
- [X] Follow our [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

comment.body:
Sorry for coming back to this late,

> Note that I'm aware that the dedupExchange blocks this duplicate request. But I'd rather consider this a workaround. The second operation should not be executed in the first place.

Basically, we actually don't consider this a workaround, because there are many reasons for this to happen. Specifically, both in `urql`'s bindings for Vue and React there are concepts of suspense and interruption respectively.

In Vue, we have both the use of the hook triggering the subscription to results reactively, while it may also be await-ed for Vue's Suspense feature, and in React the initial mount and later effect are separate, which means there are always two potential phases in which data is retrieved separately.

In other words, two operations being triggered is often representative of two separate "client-accesses".

While it's tempting to think of `urql`'s operations as "actions", they're much more like a request for data retrieval. Hence, the `dedupExchange` is important and the client actually has more mechanisms to merge identical operations into one. That's why we'd consider it a non-issue.

To get to a more general question: Do the Vue bindings when they're used with `await` _need_ to trigger two operations?

We can actually rephrase this into: Can the lazy-promise/thenable and the `watchEffect` call share the same source. The answer to that used to be no with a not so simple explanation.

When we initially tested and wrote the implementation, what we noticed is that the timing of both can wildly differ, just like in React. This means that if we share the source (via Wonka's `share` operator) we actually sometimes may get too few operations 😅

issue.title: fix(graphcache): consistent __typename removal
issue.body:
## Summary

While investigating https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/issues/2701 I noticed that we invalidate the result for a cache-hit due to not having `__typename` there, on a closer look this is because when we [`foward`](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/blob/main/exchanges/graphcache/src/cacheExchange.ts#L134) we add the `__typename` in `formatDocument`, this is also returned to the user because we have changed the operation itself, but when we get a result from cache we use the supplied query which might be missing these `__typename` additions.

To counter-act this we will always query the result with the original query in mind

## Set of changes

- preserve the original query

comment.body: Testing a different approach this in #2736, which instead tries to preserve the original document and continue to prevent adding `__typename` when it's not in the original document (which was, I believe, an issue reported in the past)

issue.title: fix(graphcache): infinite loop in dependent queries
issue.body:
## Summary

When we have a data relationship between x queries we currently end up re-triggering them when we have a cache-miss, this because of how we collect `dependencies` and `reexecute` them. To circumvent this we keep track of the operation that creates these reexecutions and we keep track of the ones that were targeted by these reexecuting origins.

This means that A can trigger B but B can't re-trigger A if B is a cache-miss.

comment.body: Testing a different approach to this in #2737

issue.title: RFC: Flexible key generation (override key field)

labels.name: documentation 📖
labels.description: This needs to be documented but won't need code changes

issue.body:
<!--
  🚨 RFCs are for proposed changes (not bugs or questions)
  Specifically they are whenever you'd like to see new features
  being added to urql, or enable new use-cases.
  They're also relevant whenever @urql/core is changed, since
  changes to e.g. the `Client` or `Exchange` types are kept rare
  and lean.
-->

## Summary

When computing the key used to normalize data for given types, the graphcache Store `keyOfEntity` is hard-coded to use `id` or `_id` value if that's present.

```ts
    let key: string | null | void;
    if (this.keys[data.__typename]) {
      key = this.keys[data.__typename](data);
    } else if (data.id != null) {
      key = `${data.id}`;
    } else if (data._id != null) {
      key = `${data._id}`;
    }
```

Consumers can prevent the use of `id` / `_id` by passing `keys` to the `cacheExchange`, but that only works per specific type / typename. There's no way to override the behavior for all types.

I'm working in a project with a large existing GraphQL schema and API that uses a different field (which I'll call `anotherId`) to indicate uniqueness in nearly all of the (hundreds of) types. I can't ask the API teams to return these fields as `id`.

urql doesn't seem to support configuring a different field globally (in a way that isn't specific to a particular `__typename`). For obvious reasons it would be clumsy to have to parse the schema to find all the types with `anotherId` merely so I can specify all of those types (mapped to a single key generator function that returns `anotherId`) inside the `keys` config.

## Proposed Solution

A flexible solution would be to support callers providing their own function that computes the key for a piece of data. Callers could then implement their own logic that is type-specific (using `__typename`), checking for the presence of their own key fields, etc. and use `id` or `_id` only if their GraphQL schema uses those.

Note that Apollo Client's `InMemoryCache` uses that approach to support a global override function which is more flexible: [Customizing identifier generation globally](https://www.apollographql.com/docs/react/caching/cache-configuration/#customizing-identifier-generation-globally)

comment.body:
Marking this under `documentation`, so that we don't forget that this is to document the Proxy approach rather than implementing something new.
I actually tried this before as well myself, and it's what I'd recommend people to do, because it's a little more transparent, without us recommending everyone to come up with some super unexpected patterns for a `keys` function. I really wouldn't want most people to create a single `keys` function and then get stuck later on, so I really like recommending proxies here :+1:

issue.title: RFC: Auth exchange reference implementations for real-world authentication services.

labels.name: future 🔮
labels.description: An enhancement or feature proposal that will be addressed after the next release

issue.body:
<!--
  🚨 RFCs are for proposed changes (not bugs or questions)
  Specifically they are whenever you'd like to see new features
  being added to urql, or enable new use-cases.
  They're also relevant whenever @urql/core is changed, since
  changes to e.g. the `Client` or `Exchange` types are kept rare
  and lean.
-->

## Summary

Provide or link to auth exchanges that target popular authentication schemes.

<!--
  Describe in a couple of words *what* you're proposing.
  If relevant, include *why* this should be addressed now.
  The problem should be clearly stated and the solution
  should be summarised.
-->

## Proposed Solution

I propose adding copy-pasteable canonical implementations of auth exchanges against certain backend schemes. We would contribute an implementation for targeting Cognito via the AWS Amplify package, as well as an apikey based one that uses a static token suitable for eg targeting Github. I'll post a separate discussion thread to harvest some others such as Auth0 that I'm sure are out there.

<!--
  Explain the solution you're proposing in detail.
  *How* will this change be implemented, and how does it work?
-->

This does not have to be runnable importable code provided by the `@urql/exchange-auth` package; it could be a separate `exchange-auth-contrib` repo, blessed links to gists, or the like.

The benefits I see:

1. As it stands, Urql gives you 99% of a production-ready solution but leaves you to write this one essential piece. If you are developing against a service that already requires auth (github, AWS amplify, AWS Api Gateway + serverless, etc) then it is impossible to evaluate urql without this chore.
2. It's straightforward code, but the kind of code that is only straightforward once you've written it one or more times. And even still I somehow we managed to introduce a diabolical bug due to improperly merging the old and new contexts.
3. This is critical security code that deserves community review
4. Better standardization of the auth exchange implementations will lead to better bug reports, as it reduces unknown variables and makes reproducible examples more straightforward. As it stands, to send a repro-repo that includes an auth exchange I would ???. Providing a recommended setup that included e.g. a static-token auth exchange targeting the github api lowers the effort significantly.

Some drawbacks:

1. A single package that provided importable code targeting multiple backend services would have an untenably heavy package.json, most of which would be unused (since you would only want one)
2. Delivering a well-tested solution is not maintainable, even apart from the difficulty of mocking the backend services
3. You likely don't want to be on the hook for people seeking advice on setting up Amplify / Auth0 / etc.

So providing runnable importable code seems untenable

There's surely some middle ground, however, that lets you disclaim direct maintenance responsibility while still improving the safety and implementation burden of URQL.

## Requirements

* an interesting initial set of concrete implementations that you would feel comfortable attaching a "Looks reasonable enough but we don't actually use or maintain that" endorsement to.
* enough signifiers in the README that takes you off the hook for maintaining the code and directs people experiencing issues to the right venue
* standards for contributing new targets

<!--
  This section is *optional*.
  But if your proposed solution has multiple ways
  of being implemented, you don't want to state how
  it may be implemented, or you don't know yet how
  it will be implemented, then:
  *List* what the implementation needs to achieve to fulfil this RFC;
-->

comment.body:
We're not interested in maintaining this because this is not something we can sustain at our current breadth of features with few core maintainers.

To suggest an alternative, feel free to publish a package that provides Cognito Authentication via the auth exchange, by wrapping it, or a similar utility package.

Cheers 🙌

comment.body:
Hm, that's true. It's indeed not always feasible to communicate client-side requirements to the schema designers.

I suppose, we can't do much about that by changing Graphcache unless this was to get moved ahead: https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/pull/2018

We have considered directives for the above (which I believe, Relay has adopted to fill this gap), but currently, we've assumed that it's safer to wait for this syntax change to land

I don't really see personally why someone would have a different limit than the defacto IETF limit on the length of URLs, which also happens to be one that all browsers align on 🤔 
I think the main reason we're adding this is if someone knows their _entire_ stack can support variable length URLs, in which case, worst case, they're opting into HTTP stack errors, which are very observable. Most likely, I'd expect to see this in backend-only applications where likely no limit really applies.

pull_request.title: feat(core): Allow GET URL limit to be ignored using force option
pull_request.body:
Resolve #2680

## Summary

This updates `preferGetMethod` to allow for one more mode, which ignores the URL size limit of 2048 characters.

The option now, apart from boolean flags, also accepts `preferGetMethod: 'within-url-limit'` and `preferGetMethod: 'force'`. This is the proposed method to allow fetch exchanges to bypass the defined limit and always send a GET request for queries.

The default remains unchanged at `preferGetMethod: true | 'within-url-limit'`

## Set of changes

- Update types to include new options for `preferGetMethod`
- Handle `preferGetMethod: 'force'`

issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Since graphcache v5.0.2 seems that queries with `requestPolicy: "network-only"` are no longer updated as before.

## Example
Query:
```
notes {
  id
  status # e.g. TODO
}
```

Mutation:
```
completeNote(id: 1, status: COMPLETED) {
  id
  status
}
```

After mutation, I see that cache is updated with `status: COMPLETED`, but query is not updated (to trigger React component rerender).

In graphcache v5.0.1 queries are updated even with `requestPolicy: "network-only"`.


### Reproduction

-

### Urql version

@urql/exchange-graphcache v5.0.2 (5.0.1 works fine)
urql v.3.0.3

issue.title: `handle.useQuery()` should only be called in the `setup()` or a lifecycle hook.
issue.body:
https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/blob/8fc678e8bf81c72d57f5cf27f03bf3b132dcf951/packages/vue-urql/src/useClientHandle.ts#L72

TL;DR Why does this code in that if statement even exist, what is its purpose

- We always have the reference to the client
- We do not need `setup` context because we have the client and `useClient` will not be called in `callUseQuery`
- This code only results in redundant console errors in a `NODE_ENV=development` staging build
- Isn't the WHOLE idea about the handle to be able to run queries in a callback, past the `setup` function context

issue.title: `handle.useQuery()` should only be called in the `setup()` or a lifecycle hook.
issue.body:
https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/blob/8fc678e8bf81c72d57f5cf27f03bf3b132dcf951/packages/vue-urql/src/useClientHandle.ts#L72

TL;DR Why does this code in that if statement even exist, what is its purpose

- We always have the reference to the client
- We do not need `setup` context because we have the client and `useClient` will not be called in `callUseQuery`
- This code only results in redundant console errors in a `NODE_ENV=development` staging build
- Isn't the WHOLE idea about the handle to be able to run queries in a callback, past the `setup` function context

comment.body:
It exists because it's not redundant and we've gotten too many issues like these unfortunately having to explain that Vue's Compositional APIs and component hooks only function inside the setup method.

> Isn't the WHOLE idea about the handle to be able to run queries in a callback, past the setup function context

Yes, but the main useClientHandle function has to be called in the setup method.

> This code only results in redundant console errors in a NODE_ENV=development staging build

The warning is limited to development builds because we don't need to enforce behaviour that's there by convention in a production build, since it'll lead to issues long before then

> We do not need setup context because we have the client and useClient will not be called in callUseQuery

The context is actually based on this: https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/blob/8fc678e8bf81c72d57f5cf27f03bf3b132dcf951/packages/vue-urql/src/useClient.ts#L26

There's also the additional reason of the setup lifecycle being needed because it's the canonical space to hook into certain effects phases and register unmount callbacks.

You can find out more about this here: https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/discussions/2422

Also, clearly I have to be a little strict on thiis. This is a question and neither adheres to our issue or RFC template, and a discussion thread would be more appropriate. But there are pre-existingn threads that do answer most of these questions already.

issue.title: React useQuery returns data from cache with "network-only"
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Hello. In my project there is a "transactions" query with relay pagination. 
cacheExchange resolvers:
```
Query: {
    transactions: relayPagination(),
}
```

I use data returned from useQuery with  requestPolicy: "network-only". And loading 10 items per request (passing "first" and "after" arguments)

```
const [{ data, fetching, error }] = useQuery({
    query,
    variables: { first: 10 },
    requestPolicy:  "network-only",
    pause
});
```
Next pages I load thought  graphqlClient returned from `useClient()`
And `data` from  `useQuery()`  is updated after completion `graphqlClient.query(...)`

For example, scenario with unexpected behaviour:
1. I go to transactions page and load two pages sequentially, after that  `data.transactions.edges` return 20 items, its ok.
2. I go to another page, so component with useQuery was unmount.
3. I go to transactions page again. useQuery starts new request for first page, arguments ` { first: 10 }`, its still ok.
4. But `data.transactions.edges ` will still return 20 items. But I expected 10 items when  "network-only" used.

Docs says that "_network-only will always send an API request and will ignore cached results."_

Сan you give me a hint how to get the expected behavior? Or is it a bug?


### Reproduction

https://codesandbox.io/s/solitary-bird-ggf8cq

### Urql version

2.2.1

### Validations

- [X] I can confirm that this is a bug report, and not a feature request, RFC, question, or discussion, for which [GitHub Discussions](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/discussions) should be used
- [X] Read the [docs](https://formidable.com/open-source/urql/docs/).
- [X] Follow our [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

comment.body:
I can convert this in a discussion in a bit, unless we find a resolution quickly, but this looks more like a question to me.

In short, just because you set `network-only`, that doesn't mean that Graphcache is fully bypassed. In fact, request policies dictate when a request should be made, but not how the response is handled. If that was the case, then any response from the GraphQL schema wouldn't run through resolvers and you'd get inconcistent results.

So to apply that to your specific case, the `relayPagination` helper is a quick and easy way to integrate Relay Pages, but `network-only` _does not_ mean that `resolvers` are bypassed. In fact, the resolvers are still applied to your API result, and triggering a `network-only` operation only means that you'll get a result from the API rather than the cache (you're telling the cache to immediately disregard its data and get an API result)

That API result is still however:
- written to the cache
- resolved against the cache
- `updates` and then `resolvers` will be run

Personally, if you're looking for a full solution, that's why we tell people when asked that _infinite pagination_ is a _UI-concern_. Your UI basically displays multiple pages, and `relayPagination` is just a quick and dirty way for the cache to take over that concern.

That's why we've got a separate non-normalised-cache pattern here: https://formidable.com/open-source/urql/docs/basics/ui-patterns/#infinite-scrolling

However, otherwise, be aware that `resolvers` always apply for the sake of consistency to API results as well, so that they actually consistently apply their changes and transformations to your GraphQL data.

issue.title: Wonka manually polyfills Symbol.observable which can cause interoperability issues with other Observable packages
issue.body: One of the issues users may run into in the current situation is that if Wonka is loaded after other Observable objects have already been created with the **pony**fill method, Wonka will polyfill the `Symbol.observable` causing packages to no longer recognise previously created observables, breaking interoperability.

issue.title: Use a ponyfill observable instead of polyfilling
issue.body:
Resolve #122

One of the issues users may run into in the current situation is that if Wonka is loaded after other Observable objects have already been created with the **pony**fill method, Wonka will polyfill the `Symbol.observable` causing packages to no longer recognise previously created observables, breaking interoperability.

This PR makes sure Wonka's behaviour matches that of other packages like [RxJS src/internal/symbol/observable.ts](https://github.com/ReactiveX/rxjs/blob/6fa819beb91ba99dadd6262d6c13f7ddfd9470c5/src/internal/symbol/observable.ts) and [redux src/utils/symbol-observable.ts](https://github.com/reduxjs/redux/blob/cf5043a4de63cb3a26dfb5e7e2d5a68d2d8a79f5/src/utils/symbol-observable.ts).

pull_request.title: Use a ponyfill observable instead of polyfilling
pull_request.body:
One of the issues users may run into in the current situation is that if Wonka is loaded after other Observable objects have already been created with the **pony**fill method, Wonka will polyfill the `Symbol.observable` causing packages to no longer recognise previously created observables, breaking interoperability.

This PR makes sure Wonka's behaviour matches that of other packages like [RxJS src/internal/symbol/observable.ts](https://github.com/ReactiveX/rxjs/blob/6fa819beb91ba99dadd6262d6c13f7ddfd9470c5/src/internal/symbol/observable.ts) and [redux src/utils/symbol-observable.ts](https://github.com/reduxjs/redux/blob/cf5043a4de63cb3a26dfb5e7e2d5a68d2d8a79f5/src/utils/symbol-observable.ts).

comment.body:
There's not much we can do without a reproduction and details, especially since a recent-ish patch already resolved one of the legitimate causes for the issue already.
See: https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/pull/2556

So, as far as this goes, a stack trace isn't sufficient for us to look into this, especially if it involves React Devtools and potentially HMR.

For what it's worth, I've never seen this warning cause actual issues or bugs, while our mitigation of the warning unfortunately used to cause bugs. That said, I'm pretty convinced that any case that'd actually cause issues has been resolved 🤔

As for common causes, if you have multiple queries in adjacent components, it's preferable to unify and compose the same query of multiple fragments and instead passing on the data. Alternatively, if you're triggering a mutation inside a render call this can also trigger this warning

For now, I'll mark this issue as incomplete, since we wouldn't have enough info to go after anything, but even with more info it's a warning that's safe to ignore afaik

pull_request.title: fix(graphcache): avoid removing subscription layers
pull_request.body:
## Summary

Previously we included subscriptions in the logic we use to layer when a result has more results coming in due to `@stream` or `@defer`. We forgot to port this line over so when we are dealing with a result that isn't optimistic but comes from a subscription we erroneously removed the previous to-be squashed layer.

issue.title: Indicate that `this` is not used, or convert functions to arrow functions
issue.body:
A few of the functions in Wonka triggers the `@typescript-eslint/unbound-method` lint rule when used. See <https://github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/blob/main/packages/eslint-plugin/docs/rules/unbound-method.md>.

For example, the makeSubject example from the documentation:

```ts
import { makeSubject } from 'wonka'
const subject = Wonka.makeSubject();
const { source, next, complete } = subject;
```

Changing `export function makeSubject<T>(): Subject<T> {` to `export function makeSubject<T>(this: void): Subject<T> {` should be enough to indicate that `this` is not used in these functions. Or it could just be an arrow function instead in which case we do not need to indicate that.

pull_request.title: fix(core): build debug target correctly
pull_request.body:
Resolves #2690 

## Summary

When leveraging `transform-debug-target`  we fill in the `source` everywhere, this does not work for the `compose.ts` file as it's not an exchange. The bug is caused by us taking the latest transformed exchange and pushing `source: name` into the object invocation, resulting in [this](https://www.runpkg.com/?@urql/core@3.0.4/dist/urql-core.js#689). This PR effectively excludes `compose.ts` and hence fixes our future builds.

pull_request.title: Fix useMenuFocus jumping to first element on Enter with no owner
pull_request.body:
# Description

Fixes an issue with the `useMenuFocus` hook, where pressing enter on any input would focus the last menu that got registered using the hook. This behavior was only meant to happen if the input was pass as an owner to the hook. This PR fixes that and introduces a test.

I ran `yarn test` locally and all tests are passing, including the new ones.

Also updates Cypress to the latest version, and some docs on how to do local development.

issue.title: errorExchange does not fire when defaultExchanges is used
errorExchange does not fire when defaultExchanges is used

comment.body:
Hiya 👋

There's more in-depth information on exchanges on this docs page and why their order matters: https://formidable.com/open-source/urql/docs/advanced/authoring-exchanges/

In short, since this exchange deals with errors in results, you'll have to put it in front (i.e. before in the array) any exchange that delivers results, which most commonly is just the `fetchExchange`.

You can put it in front of all exchanges, but it's more advisable to replace the `defaultExchanges` list with a manual one and put it directly in front of the `fetchExchange`

issue.title: Add Async Iterable support

comment.body:
Hiya :wave:

I'm not quite sure why this was opened without a description, and for now, while I'm open to reopening this of course if things change, I'll close this PR for now.

This basically has two reasons.

The first is, that I skipped support of adding a `toAsyncIterable` primitive on purpose. It's just not something I see as useful right now, and I haven't seen a lot of cases where it'd be useful, in my opinion, _just yet_. I don't exclude there being a possibility of this in the future. However, any implementation would have to be better at backpressure, meaning, it'd have to pull only when a value has resolved, and not eagerly. Currently, your implementation for instance does not handle the case of only pulling when a next value is requested.

However, again, I don't think this is something I'd want to add to the library right now.

As per `fromAsyncIterable`, Wonka already contains this, together with support for non-async-iterables: https://github.com/0no-co/wonka/blob/34ee8d777f035abacff15b5f7dc2af45ddf284b9/src/sources.ts#L9-L88

As you see, it also has a bit of a different call signature and doesn't rely on `catch(console.error)`, instead escalating this to be an uncaught error instead. Details like these are a little more important to prevent us handling errors where they shouldn't happen, where `catch` actually tells the runtime that the error is in fact being handled.

Another small detail, which `for-await-of` actually doesn't quite handle that well is the behaviour of `iterator.return` and `iterator.throw`, which is in there because it can be used in case of cancellation, and in case of skipping and swallowing errors down the chain.

review.body:
Hiya :wave: Thanks for the submission. It took me some time to sift through more sources. Basically, the original global-modifying polyfill was based on an older "copy-paste approach" from a different library, which has also reverted to this exact piece of code.

Especially due to browser support of `Symbol` in general, although `Symbol.observable` will never be present, I guess as long as the alternative is used often enough that may be fine.

However, I'll have to monitor this, as this switches the library from a non-spec standard to a defacto standard.

pull_request.title: Use a ponyfill observable instead of polyfilling
pull_request.body:
One of the issues users may run into in the current situation is that if Wonka is loaded after other Observable objects have already been created with the **pony**fill method, Wonka will polyfill the `Symbol.observable` causing packages to no longer recognise previously created observables, breaking interoperability.

This PR makes sure Wonka's behaviour matches that of other packages like [RxJS src/internal/symbol/observable.ts](https://github.com/ReactiveX/rxjs/blob/6fa819beb91ba99dadd6262d6c13f7ddfd9470c5/src/internal/symbol/observable.ts) and [redux src/utils/symbol-observable.ts](https://github.com/reduxjs/redux/blob/cf5043a4de63cb3a26dfb5e7e2d5a68d2d8a79f5/src/utils/symbol-observable.ts).

comment.body:
```suggestion
  Symbol.observable || '@@observable';
```

`wonka`, as per its most common usage in `urql`, actually makes some minimum assumptions now as per the browser support that's required. With the departure of IE11 in what's supported, it's currently assumed that support looks like:

```
last 3 ios_saf versions
last 3 and_chr major versions
op_mini > 99
and_uc > 99
last 3 samsung major versions
last 3 opera versions
last 3 safari versions
last 10 chrome major versions
last 8 firefox major versions
ie > 99
last 3 edge versions
```

hence, `Symbol` support can be assumed, and it being missing in the global scope should fail.

issue.title: Indicate that `this` is not used, or convert functions to arrow functions
issue.body:
A few of the functions in Wonka triggers the `@typescript-eslint/unbound-method` lint rule when used. See <https://github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/blob/main/packages/eslint-plugin/docs/rules/unbound-method.md>.

For example, the makeSubject example from the documentation:

```ts
import { makeSubject } from 'wonka'
const subject = Wonka.makeSubject();
const { source, next, complete } = subject;
```

Changing `export function makeSubject<T>(): Subject<T> {` to `export function makeSubject<T>(this: void): Subject<T> {` should be enough to indicate that `this` is not used in these functions. Or it could just be an arrow function instead in which case we do not need to indicate that.

comment.body:
Hiya :wave: While I'd love to accept the issue and the corresponding PR, I'm failing to determine a reason to, sorry!

To keep it short, a random ESLint rule, that is not being applied to this repository is unfortunately not a reason to accept this issue and PR. Because no function in `wonka` is actually using an execution context, whether the function ends up being called bound or unbound is irrelevant. In fact, it would be pretty odd to call it bound to any given context, as there's no relevant need to. It simply does not use prototype inheritance in any sense.
This is why the difference is merely in coding style.

What's also published in the final package output, is basically transpiled & compiled code, as per the Rollup configuration: https://github.com/0no-co/wonka/blob/main/rollup.config.js
As part of this, it's a transpilation detail of whether the functions end up being arrow functions, function expressions, or function declarations. However, writing them as function declarations has the advantage of often not being transpiled away and retaining their name even when minified. This is nice for debugging in Node environments, where sourcemaps are often not used. However, in any browsers, even with a bundler, sourcemaps are still used and make the difference between styled negligible.

I hope that makes sense to you 🙌

This pull request is aimed at increasing the reliability of our e2e, we were seeming some failures by our API answering too fast.

As a follow-up I would love to start adding graphCache, ... to this and test a real application with graphCache, another follow up would be to update to the new cypress major

- increase speed of CI by only building the core package
- add missing cypress files
- add `delayExchange` to our exchanges in e2e

pull_request.title: Version Packages
pull_request.body:
This PR was opened by the [Changesets release](https://github.com/changesets/action) GitHub action. When you're ready to do a release, you can merge this and the packages will be published to npm automatically. If you're not ready to do a release yet, that's fine, whenever you add more changesets to main, this PR will be updated.

# Releases
## @urql/exchange-graphcache@5.0.2

### Patch Changes

-   Preserve the original `DocumentNode` AST when updating the cache, to prevent results after a network request from differing and breaking referential equality due to added `__typename` fields, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2736](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/pull/2736))
-   ⚠️ Fix optimistic mutations containing partial results (`undefined` fields), which previously actually caused a hidden cache miss, which may then affect a subsequent non-optimistic mutation result, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2740](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/pull/2740))
-   Prevent cache misses from causing infinite network requests from being issued, when two operations manipulate each other while experiencing cache misses or are partially uncacheable, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2737](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/pull/2737))
-   ⚠️ Fix operation identities preventing users from deeply cloning operation contexts. Instead, we now use a client-wide counter (rolling over as needed).
    While this changes an internal data structure in `@urql/core` only, this change also affects the `offlineExchange` in `@urql/exchange-graphcache` due to it relying on the identity being previously an object rather than an integer, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2732](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/pull/2732))
-   ⚠️ Fix referential equality preservation in Graphcache failing after API results, due to a typo writing the API result rather than the updated cache result, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2741](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/pull/2741))
-   Updated dependencies (See [#2691](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/pull/2691), [#2692](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/pull/2692), and [#2732](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/pull/2732))
    -   @urql/core@3.0.4

 ## @urql/core@3.0.4

### Patch Changes

-   ⚠️ Fix `ssrExchange` bug which prevented `staleWhileRevalidate` from sending off requests as network-only requests, and caused unrelated `network-only` operations to be dropped, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2691](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/pull/2691))
-   Allow URL limit for GET requests to be bypassed using `preferGetMethod: 'force'` rather than the default `true` or `'within-url-limit'` value, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2692](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/pull/2692))
-   ⚠️ Fix operation identities preventing users from deeply cloning operation contexts. Instead, we now use a client-wide counter (rolling over as needed).
    While this changes an internal data structure in `@urql/core` only, this change also affects the `offlineExchange` in `@urql/exchange-graphcache` due to it relying on the identity being previously an object rather than an integer, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2732](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/pull/2732))

pull_request.title: fix(graphcache): Prevent refetch cycles when handling cache misses
pull_request.body:
**NOTE: This fix isn't fully verified yet and the code needs to be verified to not break any existing behaviour.**

## Summary

See prior approach in #2731.

When an operation is read from the cache, if we encounter a cache miss then a network request is sent, which subsequently updates the cache.

However, suppose an operation has several dependencies on the cache-missed operation. If any of the dependent operations then also experience a cache-miss, this will then subsequently retrigger the original operation as well. This is because any dependencies between operations will always be bi-directional by definition.

The easiest approach to solve this issue is to prevent direct cycles, meaning, if an operation triggers another, then we disallow the subsequent operation to trigger the first again, hence breaking infinite cycles.

As per the note at the top of this PR, while this is the minimum solution, we haven't verified two things, due to this being hard for us to test for currently:
- Are cache-miss cycles always transitive? In other words, can a cycle take a longer path than two operations?
- Are there any valid cases where two operations are now unable to updated in sequence? This must at all costs be prevented. There could be sequences of two operations updating in sequence that must then re-trigger a cache read for the first

At least the second statement above is guaranteed and verified by only applying this restriction to `cacheMissOps$`, i.e. the stream of operations after it has tried to read from the cache, experienced a cache miss, and are about to be forwarded.

## Set of changes

- Introduce double-set tracking to prevent operation re-execution cycles

pull_request.title: fix(graphcache): Fix partial optimistic mutation results
pull_request.body:
Resolve #2701

(NOTE: This is a missing piece that's also required to fix a new optimistic mutation case)

## Summary

This adds a missing piece of logic that we forgot to update in #2616, which allows optimistic mutations to not only be based on the field name (not alias) and nested functions, but also to return partial results.

Previously to this fix, partial mutation updates would cause cache misses by deleting cache values instead of skipping them.

## Set of changes

- Skip `undefined` fields on optimistic mutation results

pull_request.title: fix(graphcache): Use original operation document when updating the cache
pull_request.body:
Resolve #2701

## Summary

This prevents us from using the formatted GraphQL document, as per the output of `@urql/core`'s `formatDocument`, in Graphcache's later stage to query data against the cache. This is problematic because it changes the shape of data and hence disallows us to preserve referential equality of any given data.

Instead, we now use existing data structures to retrieve the original operation before it's been forwarded to the next exchanges.

## Set of changes

- Retrieve the original operation when writing a query result to the cache

pull_request.title: fix(core): Fix OperationContext._identity not allowing operation contexts to be deeply cloned
pull_request.body:
Resolve #2726

## Summary

While we don't imply or implicitly disallow cloning `OperationContext`, and it's definitely not expected and encouraged, if it's done, it can have some unexpected consequences.

Specifically, if an `OperationContext` is deeply cloned rather than spread, then `OperationContext._identity` is destroyed. This leads to the `Client` not being able to find the right mutation result for a given operation with an unknown `_identity`.

Previously, we assigned identities with an empty array (`[]`). There are alternatives, of course, like `{}`, symbols, functions, etc. But all may be instances that will be swapped out by users.
Instead, we now assign a numeric ID to the field, which is marked as an opaque type in TypeScript. This is a rolling-over 32-bit counter, which is sufficient to prevent mutation results from being confused.

**More importantly, this change makes `OperationContext` serializable in all cases again.**

## Set of changes

- Replace `OperationContext._identity` with a `number` ID based on a 32-bit roll-over

issue.title: Offline exchange: separate queries on same nullable object causes infinite network requests
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

There is an edge case which causes the offlineExchange to infinitely send network request.

This occurs when calling multiple `useQuery` hooks with different queries for different data on the same nullable object. Additionally the bug only occurs when the api returns `null` for the object but does not occur if the root data is `null`

This bug only occurs when using the offlineExchange.

issue.title: Operations get duplicated

labels.name: won't fix 🛑
labels.description: This issue won't be fixed as part of the current roadmap

issue.body:
### Describe the bug

I use urql in a nuxt 3 project and see duplicated operations when they should only get triggered once.

```
[Exchange debug]: Incoming operation:  
{key: 3495087222, query: Object, variables: Object, kind: "query", context: Object}
{timestamp: 1663681014862, source: "fetchExchange", type: "fetchRequest", message: "A fetch request is being executed.", operation: Object…}
[Exchange debug]: Incoming operation:  
{key: 3495087222, query: Object, variables: Object, kind: "query", context: Object}
{timestamp: 1663681014865, source: "fetchExchange", type: "dedup", message: "An operation has been deduped.", operation: Object}
{timestamp: 1663681015610, source: "fetchExchange", type: "fetchSuccess", message: "A successful fetch response has been returned.", operation: Object…}
```

Note that I'm aware that the `dedupExchange` blocks this duplicate request. But I'd rather consider this a workaround. The second operation should not be executed in the first place.

I added some `console.log()` to the urql sources and was able to track it down to this part of the code in `client.ts`:

https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/blob/0582f9b138ddb66c5164b00a978aac90e865c0dc/packages/core/src/client.ts#L302

The callback passed to `make()` gets called **twice** and hence the same operation in `onStart()` is dispatched again somehow. I could not figure out, why this happens.

The documentation on Wonka's [make](https://wonka.kitten.sh/api/sources#make) says:

> The function you pass to make is called lazily when a sink subscribes to the source you’re creating.

So I would expect that this is only called once. Not sure if this is maybe rather a bug in wonka.


### Reproduction

https://codesandbox.io/s/urql-duplicate-operation-yfp2ei

### Urql version

* @urql/core 3.0.3
* @urql/vue 1.0.2

### Validations

- [X] I can confirm that this is a bug report, and not a feature request, RFC, question, or discussion, for which [GitHub Discussions](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/discussions) should be used
- [X] Read the [docs](https://formidable.com/open-source/urql/docs/).
- [X] Follow our [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

comment.body:
Sorry for coming back to this late,

> Note that I'm aware that the dedupExchange blocks this duplicate request. But I'd rather consider this a workaround. The second operation should not be executed in the first place.

Basically, we actually don't consider this a workaround, because there are many reasons for this to happen. Specifically, both in `urql`'s bindings for Vue and React there are concepts of suspense and interruption respectively.

In Vue, we have both the use of the hook triggering the subscription to results reactively, while it may also be await-ed for Vue's Suspense feature, and in React the initial mount and later effect are separate, which means there are always two potential phases in which data is retrieved separately.

In other words, two operations being triggered is often representative of two separate "client-accesses".

While it's tempting to think of `urql`'s operations as "actions", they're much more like a request for data retrieval. Hence, the `dedupExchange` is important and the client actually has more mechanisms to merge identical operations into one. That's why we'd consider it a non-issue.

To get to a more general question: Do the Vue bindings when they're used with `await` _need_ to trigger two operations?

We can actually rephrase this into: Can the lazy-promise/thenable and the `watchEffect` call share the same source. The answer to that used to be no with a not so simple explanation.

When we initially tested and wrote the implementation, what we noticed is that the timing of both can wildly differ, just like in React. This means that if we share the source (via Wonka's `share` operator) we actually sometimes may get too few operations 😅

issue.title: fix(graphcache): consistent __typename removal
issue.body:
## Summary

While investigating https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/issues/2701 I noticed that we invalidate the result for a cache-hit due to not having `__typename` there, on a closer look this is because when we [`foward`](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/blob/main/exchanges/graphcache/src/cacheExchange.ts#L134) we add the `__typename` in `formatDocument`, this is also returned to the user because we have changed the operation itself, but when we get a result from cache we use the supplied query which might be missing these `__typename` additions.

To counter-act this we will always query the result with the original query in mind

## Set of changes

- preserve the original query

comment.body: Testing a different approach this in #2736, which instead tries to preserve the original document and continue to prevent adding `__typename` when it's not in the original document (which was, I believe, an issue reported in the past)

issue.title: fix(graphcache): infinite loop in dependent queries
issue.body:
## Summary

When we have a data relationship between x queries we currently end up re-triggering them when we have a cache-miss, this because of how we collect `dependencies` and `reexecute` them. To circumvent this we keep track of the operation that creates these reexecutions and we keep track of the ones that were targeted by these reexecuting origins.

This means that A can trigger B but B can't re-trigger A if B is a cache-miss.

comment.body: Testing a different approach to this in #2737

issue.title: RFC: Flexible key generation (override key field)

labels.name: documentation 📖
labels.description: This needs to be documented but won't need code changes

issue.body:
<!--
  🚨 RFCs are for proposed changes (not bugs or questions)
  Specifically they are whenever you'd like to see new features
  being added to urql, or enable new use-cases.
  They're also relevant whenever @urql/core is changed, since
  changes to e.g. the `Client` or `Exchange` types are kept rare
  and lean.
-->

## Summary

When computing the key used to normalize data for given types, the graphcache Store `keyOfEntity` is hard-coded to use `id` or `_id` value if that's present.

```ts
    let key: string | null | void;
    if (this.keys[data.__typename]) {
      key = this.keys[data.__typename](data);
    } else if (data.id != null) {
      key = `${data.id}`;
    } else if (data._id != null) {
      key = `${data._id}`;
    }
```

Consumers can prevent the use of `id` / `_id` by passing `keys` to the `cacheExchange`, but that only works per specific type / typename. There's no way to override the behavior for all types.

I'm working in a project with a large existing GraphQL schema and API that uses a different field (which I'll call `anotherId`) to indicate uniqueness in nearly all of the (hundreds of) types. I can't ask the API teams to return these fields as `id`.

urql doesn't seem to support configuring a different field globally (in a way that isn't specific to a particular `__typename`). For obvious reasons it would be clumsy to have to parse the schema to find all the types with `anotherId` merely so I can specify all of those types (mapped to a single key generator function that returns `anotherId`) inside the `keys` config.

## Proposed Solution

A flexible solution would be to support callers providing their own function that computes the key for a piece of data. Callers could then implement their own logic that is type-specific (using `__typename`), checking for the presence of their own key fields, etc. and use `id` or `_id` only if their GraphQL schema uses those.

Note that Apollo Client's `InMemoryCache` uses that approach to support a global override function which is more flexible: [Customizing identifier generation globally](https://www.apollographql.com/docs/react/caching/cache-configuration/#customizing-identifier-generation-globally)

comment.body:
Marking this under `documentation`, so that we don't forget that this is to document the Proxy approach rather than implementing something new.
I actually tried this before as well myself, and it's what I'd recommend people to do, because it's a little more transparent, without us recommending everyone to come up with some super unexpected patterns for a `keys` function. I really wouldn't want most people to create a single `keys` function and then get stuck later on, so I really like recommending proxies here :+1:

pull_request.title: fix(core): Fix OperationContext._identity not allowing operation contexts to be deeply cloned
pull_request.body:
Resolve #2726

## Summary

While we don't imply or implicitly disallow cloning `OperationContext`, and it's definitely not expected and encouraged, if it's done, it can have some unexpected consequences.

Specifically, if an `OperationContext` is deeply cloned rather than spread, then `OperationContext._identity` is destroyed. This leads to the `Client` not being able to find the right mutation result for a given operation with an unknown `_identity`.

Previously, we assigned identities with an empty array (`[]`). There are alternatives, of course, like `{}`, symbols, functions, etc. But all may be instances that will be swapped out by users.
Instead, we now assign a numeric ID to the field, which is marked as an opaque type in TypeScript. This is a rolling-over 32-bit counter, which is sufficient to prevent mutation results from being confused.

**More importantly, this change makes `OperationContext` serializable in all cases again.**

## Set of changes

- Replace `OperationContext._identity` with a `number` ID based on a 32-bit roll-over

issue.title: RFC: Auth exchange reference implementations for real-world authentication services.

labels.name: future 🔮
labels.description: An enhancement or feature proposal that will be addressed after the next release

issue.body:
<!--
  🚨 RFCs are for proposed changes (not bugs or questions)
  Specifically they are whenever you'd like to see new features
  being added to urql, or enable new use-cases.
  They're also relevant whenever @urql/core is changed, since
  changes to e.g. the `Client` or `Exchange` types are kept rare
  and lean.
-->

## Summary

Provide or link to auth exchanges that target popular authentication schemes.

<!--
  Describe in a couple of words *what* you're proposing.
  If relevant, include *why* this should be addressed now.
  The problem should be clearly stated and the solution
  should be summarised.
-->

## Proposed Solution

I propose adding copy-pasteable canonical implementations of auth exchanges against certain backend schemes. We would contribute an implementation for targeting Cognito via the AWS Amplify package, as well as an apikey based one that uses a static token suitable for eg targeting Github. I'll post a separate discussion thread to harvest some others such as Auth0 that I'm sure are out there.

<!--
  Explain the solution you're proposing in detail.
  *How* will this change be implemented, and how does it work?
-->

This does not have to be runnable importable code provided by the `@urql/exchange-auth` package; it could be a separate `exchange-auth-contrib` repo, blessed links to gists, or the like.

The benefits I see:

1. As it stands, Urql gives you 99% of a production-ready solution but leaves you to write this one essential piece. If you are developing against a service that already requires auth (github, AWS amplify, AWS Api Gateway + serverless, etc) then it is impossible to evaluate urql without this chore.
2. It's straightforward code, but the kind of code that is only straightforward once you've written it one or more times. And even still I somehow we managed to introduce a diabolical bug due to improperly merging the old and new contexts.
3. This is critical security code that deserves community review
4. Better standardization of the auth exchange implementations will lead to better bug reports, as it reduces unknown variables and makes reproducible examples more straightforward. As it stands, to send a repro-repo that includes an auth exchange I would ???. Providing a recommended setup that included e.g. a static-token auth exchange targeting the github api lowers the effort significantly.

Some drawbacks:

1. A single package that provided importable code targeting multiple backend services would have an untenably heavy package.json, most of which would be unused (since you would only want one)
2. Delivering a well-tested solution is not maintainable, even apart from the difficulty of mocking the backend services
3. You likely don't want to be on the hook for people seeking advice on setting up Amplify / Auth0 / etc.

So providing runnable importable code seems untenable

There's surely some middle ground, however, that lets you disclaim direct maintenance responsibility while still improving the safety and implementation burden of URQL.

## Requirements

* an interesting initial set of concrete implementations that you would feel comfortable attaching a "Looks reasonable enough but we don't actually use or maintain that" endorsement to.
* enough signifiers in the README that takes you off the hook for maintaining the code and directs people experiencing issues to the right venue
* standards for contributing new targets

<!--
  This section is *optional*.
  But if your proposed solution has multiple ways
  of being implemented, you don't want to state how
  it may be implemented, or you don't know yet how
  it will be implemented, then:
  *List* what the implementation needs to achieve to fulfil this RFC;
-->

comment.body:
We're not interested in maintaining this because this is not something we can sustain at our current breadth of features with few core maintainers.

To suggest an alternative, feel free to publish a package that provides Cognito Authentication via the auth exchange, by wrapping it, or a similar utility package.

Cheers 🙌

issue.title: useQuery not returning stable references
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

I hope that I'm simply misunderstanding or have misconfigured something, but I can't seem to figure out why objects inside `useQuery().data.MyQuery.someList[index]` are changing references. This means they cannot be memoized, and the application rerenders unnecessarily

* On initial load, the TodosList and every Todo renders three times
* Upon creating or updating a todo, each individual Todo in the list rerenders

Thanks :)

For skimming (if you don't want to pull the repro repo):

![Screen Shot 2022-09-23 at 4 05 03 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1881761/192056778-58a3a68a-8e48-4fa5-9b14-6ff924b895c0.png)

![urql-memo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1881761/192056828-fd2592e8-ada1-4f27-b4ff-8f4d7a20ad55.gif)

https://github.com/sarink/urql-perf/pull/2

issue.title: Unable to create offline todos app

labels.name: needs more info ✋
labels.description: A question or report that needs more info to be addressable

issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Issues:

1. User is online, creates/updates some items, the connection is interrupted, but the user continues creating/updating items, the connection comes back, and suddenly a bunch of the user's modifications have been wiped out

![urql-offline](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1881761/182265566-f7be0ebb-81ff-4b16-85cb-ba5a9018fa51.gif)



2. Invalidation does not seem to work. I don't really understand why, but, invalidating yields an empty `useQuery[0].data` object.

I would love to understand what's missing from this code, because it looks pretty much identical to [these docs](https://formidable.com/open-source/urql/docs/graphcache/cache-updates/), yet, does not behave as I would expect it to.

Your help is very much appreciated, thank you!

### Reproduction

https://github.com/sarink/urql-perf/pull/1

### Urql version

2.2.3

### Validations

- [ ] I can confirm that this is a bug report, and not a feature request, RFC, question, or discussion, for which [GitHub Discussions](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/discussions) should be used
- [X] Read the [docs](https://formidable.com/open-source/urql/docs/).
- [X] Follow our [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

comment.body:
Hm, that's true. It's indeed not always feasible to communicate client-side requirements to the schema designers.

I suppose, we can't do much about that by changing Graphcache unless this was to get moved ahead: https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/pull/2018

We have considered directives for the above (which I believe, Relay has adopted to fill this gap), but currently, we've assumed that it's safer to wait for this syntax change to land

I don't really see personally why someone would have a different limit than the defacto IETF limit on the length of URLs, which also happens to be one that all browsers align on 🤔 
I think the main reason we're adding this is if someone knows their _entire_ stack can support variable length URLs, in which case, worst case, they're opting into HTTP stack errors, which are very observable. Most likely, I'd expect to see this in backend-only applications where likely no limit really applies.

pull_request.title: feat(core): Allow GET URL limit to be ignored using force option
pull_request.body:
Resolve #2680

## Summary

This updates `preferGetMethod` to allow for one more mode, which ignores the URL size limit of 2048 characters.

The option now, apart from boolean flags, also accepts `preferGetMethod: 'within-url-limit'` and `preferGetMethod: 'force'`. This is the proposed method to allow fetch exchanges to bypass the defined limit and always send a GET request for queries.

The default remains unchanged at `preferGetMethod: true | 'within-url-limit'`

## Set of changes

- Update types to include new options for `preferGetMethod`
- Handle `preferGetMethod: 'force'`
